description: I've been coming here for over 10 years! Hands down best tacos, burritos, aguas frescos, chips, and salsa bar in the city! I think it even beats out El Farollito in the Mission. Carne Asada is delicious and so is the carnitas!
author: Desiree B.

description:
The burritos were good and the restaurant seemed clean but Oh My God is this place in a terrible neighborhood. 

I was dropped off in front of the place and from the walk to the front door of the taco shop (15 feet), I was accosted by two men saying I was "in the wrong hood cuz". 

I like the mission style burritos (Super Burrito as they call them) but the California burritos in San Diego are superior
author: Nathan P.

description:
We came here because it was close to our hotel and we didnt feel like going somewhere that far. 

Pretty empty on sunday lunch, only had a few customers inside. Menu isnt that large but food is yummy. We ordered a wheat tortilla vegetarian burrito & a wheat tortilla lengua burrito. The lengua super burrito was huge and i was only able to eat half of it. There were large chunks of moist lengua in every bite, and the burrito wasnt too salty or anything at all.   I would definitely come here again if i was in this area. Service was friendly and restaurant was mostly pretty clean.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Burritos are very Tiny .I asked for a Super Burrito and I was Told they down sized. I am going elsewhere.After a hard days work I was looking forward to a Burrito.Very Very Dissapointed.The special of the day was Camarones ala Diabla it was watered Down Valentina sauce I hate to Put Them Down but I had better food .I don't know why the Change I remember when This place Had Great Food.Hopefully Management or The owner Reads this
author: Abel M.

description:
Go elsewhere. Not only did the person behind me got their order before mine, but the cook was very slow at cooking, AND got my order wrong. I also tipped them $4 before all of that. Never again. 

I mean the food is still alright, but obviously they don't care. She was letting a drunk finish up his conversation and they still proceeded to talk while I was trying to order. Anyway. Stay away. The area is shady too. Some guy tried to sell me Xanax outside.... hence why I was trying to leave quick too.
author: Su R.

description:
Clearly ppl who rated this highly accidentally rated it instead of the place down the street which is Zagat rated. I accidentally came here intending to go to the other place. The chicken is very disappointing and they keep the place at a balmy 84 degrees. 

Quesadilla had almost no cheese. Tacos were also bad. Common thread: the chicken
author: Adrian V.

description: Not quite sure how this place has received so many good reviews. The food is horrible here and way over priced. I didn't have a bad experience with staff, this is purely based on my extensive travels and having really good Mexican food. Do yourself the favor and save your money because you will be disappointed.
author: Amber O.

description: Bland, totally bland. Chicken has no flavor. Restaurant seems to have no interest in authentic Mexican food. Would not return.
author: Kay C.

description:
Visiting San Francisco (and the US), I've made it a goal to visit as many taquerias as possible. No where else have I had such good Mexican food (though I haven't been to South America yet!).

Unfortunately, I didn't feel this restaurant lived up to the standard in other places around town.

Firstly, the area is not the best. I can't blame the restaurant for that but it would be much nicer if they took card. There's currently a cash machine by the entrance but since it's not from a brand bank (and once again since the area doesn't feel the safest), I don't feel especially comfortable taking money out.

Regarding the food: I was recommended to try the California burrito-which I did-but I wasn't satisfied. It tasted pretty bland. The portions where big so that's a benefit I guess. 

What really put me off though, was the apparent hygiene and sanitary standards. To get the nachos, clients themselves grab a little bucket of chips from a pile of these buckets. You inevitably touch other people's and this could be instantly improved by just handing it to people. Someone else's review also mentioned a cockroach or something. I don't think this is too crazy considering the look of the place. I think a deep clean is in order.

The staff were nice and helpful though, a redeeming feature of the restaurant. Also, I think some of the other burritos could be good - I was put off by the apparent sanitation and may have judged the food too early.
author: Michael C.

description:
Got a steak super burrito, it was alright. Nothing to write home about. Price for that and a can of soda was 12 bucks so reasonable prices. 

Cash only 

The place smells horrible. Like a septic issue or water damage. Something old and funky as hell. 

Wouldn't come back.
author: Alessandra N.

description:
Today I spent 5 HOURS trying to get Hamilton tickets for my mother in a different city.  I succeeded only after calling and texting her and double checking dates, times, seating arrangements, are the seats near the aisle? blah blah blah.  5 hours later, she was finally satisfied and my beautiful boyfriend took me out of the house.  We tried going to Morty's since we hadn't been in a while but it was closed and El Castillito Star was there to save the day.

I got to have a breakfast burrito at 3pm and it was glorious.  Other places have a cheaper cut of chorizo but this one was spot on.  It's 1 of 3 Mexican places I'll go to in this area although there's a lot in this neighborhood.  The others just can't live up to my expectations.

CASH ONLY.
author: Ashley I.

description:
With limited options around the area and a craving for something heavy, I passed up my usual 3 spring rolls for Mexican food.  I was contemplating between the cheese quesadilla or the carnitas and cheese quesadilla and the meat and cheese won.  After placing my order, my friend and I watched the food prepper put together a HUGE burrito.  Cancel your quesadilla! He says, Cancel it!!! So I immediately cancelled it and we split the burrito instead.  

Super burrito with chicken - The burrito was good but it was lacking something.  Once we added some spicy sauce from the nacho stand, it gave it more flavor

After finishing our food and making our way out, I stood there and froze as I watched a lady holding a switchblade like she was going to shank someone (slowly walks behind her and speed walks across the street).  That's Tenderloin for ya.
author: Linda N.

description: I got the veggie burrito, and it's definitely just okay. Says avocado but there was none. :( Cold veggies, lots of rice. Not the worst, just not worth 9 bucks.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
We went to this restaurant during the Pride parade and it was one of the very few places that accepts credit cards because I usually don't carry cash.

The line was pretty long, about 10 minutes. The burritos are what they are known for and I decided to get the breakfast burrito and had it cooked spicy. The burrito itself was AMAZING. They also give you free chips and the salsa verde was spicy which was perfect!

Although the only negative experience I had was that they messed up on my transaction and charged me for the wrong thing.

Overall, I recommend this place and try their burritos! I would love to come back here and try some more of their entrees.
author: Aj C.

description: I hate to be one of those people that write a negative yelp review, but I'm sure there are plenty of other places out there. If you come here, PLEASE order your salsa on the side. It is so spicy that it brings tears to your eyes and water to your nose. It also helps to speak Spanish, just like at any other taqueria. The food is edible, but not much more than that. The food is lacking in flavor, so they just cover that up with more salsa...
author: Sarah J.

description: This place was very welcoming and accepting as a business that served lunch to Pride 2016 attendees. Although the only choices were Tacos and Burritos, due to the volume of business the tacos were spicy and delicious! If my partner and I were in the area again we would definitely go here to experience more.
author: Jason C.

description:
First time having Castillos in two years and it's still as good as I remember! Yum!

Most authentic Mexican taqueria in sf outside of the mission in my opinion. Food is affordable and fulfilling. I always get the street tacos which never disappoint. Especially the hot sauce. 


There's about 3 of these taquerias. It's in a sketchier part of SF but if your in the area give them a try.
author: Nicole V.

description: We found a cockroach in the juice. They refunded our money but continued to serve the juice. Eat at your own risk.
author: L L.

description: I was happy to find a Mexican spot so close to work. After reading all the great reviews I made my way here. Unfortunately, I came during the peak of lunch hour rush and had to wait in a long line before being served, which was ok since it bought me time to look at all the different menu options. I ordered their meat quesadilla, which was huge and very filling. I would definitely recommend this place. If you plan on going during lunch, know that you can order over the phone so it's ready by the time you arrive.
author: Andy H.

description:
224. One word: impressive. For a burrito shop that's not in the Mission, this place is amazing.

I got the super burrito with pollo asado.  It was SO FAT.  Took me two meals to get through it.  I love love love the fact that they add avocado, not guacamole.  +1 for keeping it real.

I also like their setup of the sides-- the chips are already in bags/trays and the salsas are already prepared in small containers.  It's more sanitary and convenient for customers.

Yes, $9 for a burrito is pricey, but they justify it well.  I don't mind supporting this local business because they know what they're doing.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Pros:  cheap, easy, convenient location, food is alright. Service is nice too.

Cons: smells like ass. Portion size is too big for me, since I lack self control!

Length for the length god
author: B H.

description:
This review is by a Mexican who loves tacos:

The tacos here are hella good.

Got two carnitas tacos for lunch. Together with the bag of chips, my tummy was set until dinner time. 

The tacos are done properly on a double layer of small corn tortillas along with the standard taco fixings. Just the right amount of spiciness - not too mild, not too hot. The carnitas tacos juice dripped in such a way that made me proud of my people. 

They don't skimp on the meat. I shared some carnitas chunks with a friendly dog friend, not just because I'm nice but because I ate too many chips and wanted to be able to fold together the last bites of my taco. I had too much meat to fold it- and that is an excellent problem to have.

Bravo, El Castillito on your fine taco-making. You made my heart swoon.
author: Loli L.

description: Health score 100 out of 100! Boo yeah!! This place just keeps getting better.  So affordable. So good. So quick. So filling.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Hola! Located in the beautiful Tenderloin district of San Francisco, this gem of a place should be a great alternative should you choose not to eat in Little Saigon. Well its either this or Taco Bell. Take your pick.

I work nearby so I have the luxury of being a regular. I've ordered three things...burritos, tacos, and the taco salad. pollo asada or steak. All of them really good. Tacos are on point and are the real deal. So so good. Wish I could wash them down with a Corona or two but alas I am on the clock.

Good job and definitely good eats!
author: Kris P.

description:
Extremely delicious. We thought this place closed at 5pm and we almost skipped it but we were glad to find out they close at 9:30 pm. 

I got the California burrito with half pastor and asada. Delicious...especially the salsa selection.

My husband had the wet burrito half chicken and half asada...Both our meals were hot and very fresh. 

The employees are nice...so thank you for the awesome food.

We walked out spending $20 on both meals with one drink (not bad).

If it wasn't because the horchata was watered down I would have given it 5 stars.
author: Rocio M.

description:
Tasty burrito! They also have a California burrito with fries instead of rice and beans - will come back to try next time! 

Salsa verde goes great with free accompanying chips.
author: Hayley T.

description:
OMG this location is terrible. It's gotten worse throughout the years.
Yesterday I paid $8.47 for a super carne asada burrito. A burrito that costs over $8!? BLASPHEMOUS. That's some Chipotle bull$hit nonsense! The prices I pay for my damn burrito cravings in the TL.. UGH! 

First, my super burrito had no avocado.
Secondly, the carne asada was grey colored, dry, and hard.
Lastly, they have no radishes at this location.

Dear Burrito gods, please let the other Castillito reopen!
author: Susy C.

description:
A BOMB ASS BURRITO IN THE TENDERLOIN?!?!?

Amidst all the Vietnamese and South East Asian Restaurants in Little Saigon lies El Castillito, an unassuming taqueria where you can get one of the BEST burritos in SF! For the price of one bowl of pho, you can get a GIGANTIC burrito enough for 2 meals. Skeptical? Yup, I was too...

Over 2.5 years ago, when first I moved to the public sector, some of my co-workers raved about this taqueria in the TL. After having an awful case of food poisoning, I was weary of taquerias especially one that was located in the TL. Plus, back then I wasn't an avid Yelper, so it didn't even dawn on me to Yelp it.  So while my co-workers would grab a burrito at El Castillito, I would go to Saigon Sandwich at the corner to grab a banh mi.

FAST FORWARD 2.5 YEARS...

I owed one of my friends dinner and he wanted a burrito, so after a quick Yelp search it led me to El Castillito. It was close to my work and with an overall 4 Star Rating, I thought I give that a shot. As per Yelper's recommendations, I got an Al Pastor Wet Super Burrito (burrito smothered in a red chili sauce, topped with melted shredded cheese, sour cream and slices of avocado). It came with free chips and salsa. The total was just ~$7.50! I had to carry the heavy box with two hands so my clumsy self wouldn't drop it. I later get a text from him saying, "Where did you get that burrito? It was the BEST burrito I've ever had!" Ok, now my suspicions were alleviated.

This was 2 weeks ago and since then I've come to El Castillito twice for their Lengua Burrito. I get it with no beans and with avocado. For just $6.04 (including tax), I have two mouth-watering, coma-inducing meals. 
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RF-ciAQlmV2BO4lVvmfrkg?select=sa_3eNwjrk5asAn2gyZo8Q 

The burrito is GIGANTIC with a 70/30 ratio of lengua to rice. Packed inside a warm, soft freshly grilled flour tortilla skin is lengua SO soft that it melts in your mouth like buttah and is perfectly seasoned to bring out its natural rich beefyness. The seasoned rice is al-dente, yet soft and the accoutrements of pico de gallo and cilantro gives the burrito moisture with a burst of freshness while the thick slices of avocado add a layer of butteryness. 

Being a muscle, lengua can often be tough and chewy. If cooked properly, lengua should be soft and more tender than a fine filet mignon. So, lengua is normally my go-to meat to test how well a taqueria can prepare and cook their meat. The braised lengua at El Castillito BEATS the one from El Farolito, Pacho Villa, El Toro, and Taqueria Guadalajara; just to name a few. And it's second best to the lengua at La Taqueria which is much pricier at smaller portions. So, if you're a lengua fanatic like myself, you MUST try the lengua burrito at El Castillito!

The tortilla chips are nothing to rave about as they taste store bought, BUT make sure to grab several containers of the Salsa Verde--it's like liquid crack! The salsa verde is fresh, rich and creamy from the small bits of avocado and adds a nice, mild kick to your burrito.

SOME THINGS TO NOTE:

*CASH ONLY (there's a Wells Fargo ATM next door)
*Closes everyday at 10 PM
*The area is sketchy so try to find parking on Golden Gate or on Larkin where there's more foot traffic. Even though Hyde is just a block down, it's a lot MORE sketchier.

Huge, mouth-watering burrito BUSTING with meat at the seams? CHECK!
Liquid crack salsa verde? CHECK! 
Dirt cheap prices? CHECK!

Don't let the location fool you (like it did me), El Castillito is truly a hidden gem in the TL!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: This place is in a sketchy neighborhood but overall the food tasted fresh and amazing. I was full off of half a torta and it came with a lot of av
author: Alexis D.

description:
3-4 times a week now, I go here for a late lunch/snack.  My preference??  A carnitas taco.  Major tip:  the later you go, the more meat they put in the taco.  The last 5-6 times, my taco had enough meat for at least two tacos, maybe three.

Ain't nothing like a meaty taco.

Ya feel me?
author: Johnny L.

description: As fantastic as other reviewers led me to believe! Well worth the price and the fish tacos were fantastic. The salsa bar is on point and the atmosphere is laid back. Don't miss it.
author: Becca H.

description:
Absolutely love their prawn burrito. Twelve monster prawns nestled in a hot bed of rice, beans of your choosing, salsa, sour cream, and avocado slices (which is way better than guac on a burrito). I mean, really, what's not to love?

Also, they make an amazing salsa verde that has a delicious kick to it. Pair it with chips or your burrito and you are in for an awesome taste sensation!
author: N'olo J.

description:
This burrito was great because the cheese was added first, to a tortilla that had just been heated up, so the cheese was melty and fantastic. 

Really no complaints here. Good burrito, good price, friendly and quick service. Made a great study break from Philz down the street!
author: Marilyn M.

description:
Really fantastic burritos the size of your head! My neighborhood (Hayes Valley) doesn't have a lot of options for simple Mexican food, so being able to walk to this place is a godsend. Too bad about the neighborhood but it is what it is. Don't be like me and ride your bike over here or else it will be stolen in 30 seconds as mine was. 

But back to the point. Great burritos!!
author: Amber G.

description:
Last night I had the worst burrito of my life here. I really should have trusted my gut and run far away from this place the moment I arrived. I arrived at 7pm, but it was dark and sketchy outside and there was not a single customer inside. I refused to believe the place could be bad based on the other Yelp reviews. Bad idea.

I ordered a super burrito to go. It had carnitas, avocado, black beans, no sour cream upon my request. Based on the other reviews of this place, I was expecting pure bliss as I took my first bite, but was sorely surprised by how dry it was. What was it missing? Cheese! Why doesn't this burrito have any cheese???? I was tempted to go buy cheese to add to this terrible mistake of a dinner. 

Not only was it missing cheese, it was also missing any sort of moisture at all. The carnitas were the saltiest, driest pieces of meat I have ever had in my life. My friend who got the wet burrito with carne asada was also disappointed. His also had no cheese and his steak was tough and dry. 

Luckily, I found some hot sauce back home and drenched the burrito in it to make it at least edible. For $10, the burrito was not a good value at all. It was not that large or tasty. I'll never come back again.
author: Katherine Y.

description:
During my trip to SF I made a concerted effort to hit up as many taquerias as possible. 

El Farolito, Cancun, and Paplote come to mind.

I like to try the same meat (pastor in this instance) to compare the burritos. And Castillo probably finished the highest in my rankings. The meat was salty, fatty, and everything you'd want from your pastor. 

The only thing that turned me off was the 85 health score ranking, but if you can look past that, you can get yourself an amazing burrito for under $10.
author: Jason B.

description:
i had been looking for places in the mission for the best tacos in the city... but little did i know that this place was hidden right behind my school! 

there are reasons that i don't like lurking behind my school. this is because it involves getting yelled at (not holler-ed at - there is a difference), finding syringes on the floor, seeing trails of blood, and the occasional theft attempt + a shooting in december. 

BUT ALL THOSE THINGS ASIDE, coming here in the day time isn't too bad. it's right next to the post office and has awesome tacos for under $2.50 that come with a bag of chips. there's a fresh salsa bar on the side that is spicier than it looks, too. MIX THE SALSAs together!

you have to ask for napkins if you use more than the average person.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place was close to my old work place, but I found myself driving out there to make a visit because I remember their carne asada burritos being SOOO tasty!

What I like about this place:
Has black beans as an option, so I can be somewhat healthy. 
They use fresh avocados and cilantro-- YUM!
The workers there are very friendly. While this place is cash only, I was short $1 and some change. (Cause the prices went up!) So, the lady said it was fine and didn't make me take more cash out of the ATM. What great customer service!
They have salsa (am in LOVE with the green one!) in small containers all ready for you to take so you don't have to do it yourself.

What I don't like about this place:
One of the things I first noticed was the price. Their prices has definitely gone up! 
Their tortilla chips. I doubt they make them in-house. They seem like the ones you can get pre-packaged from the grocery store. (I don't think they are whole grain either, like some people have posted???)

Overall, a great place for me to get my burrito fix!
author: Mimie L.

description:
My go-to spot for burrito in the Civic Center area.  The super burrito is huge, almost the size of my forearm.  And it is only the few spots that open on major holidays. Make sure to get the super burrito since they add sour cream and guacamole.   

Plus for having beer!
Minus for not having a salsa stand like other burrito shops.  You only have the regular salsa and the green avocado only.

CASH ONLY.
author: Elliot Y.

description:
I've been eating here regularly for the last three years or so, and I keep to the carnitas. Oh boy are the carnitas delicious, and cooked the right way. They don't pre-shred it or cook it mushy or anything like that - it is just one big hunk of flavorful, fatty fried pork that they chop up to order. I can't vouch for anything else, because I only eat there once a week so I keep with what I know is awesome.

HOWEVER, recently they have reduced their portions and definitely jacked up their prices. $8.00 for a quesadilla is ridiculous, especially from a dive in the Tenderloin.
author: Dan M.

description: Awesome burritos!!! I love this place for their appreciation of Mexican food and the people are very nice on top of that! My fave is the chicken burrito, no beans. Yum!!!! If you're in the area, definitely stop by. I've seen other people's food as well and it all looks yummy!!
author: Sandra P.

description:
Not the most luxurious, but for golden gate TL, I couldn't ask for more. 

The food is delicious! I've eaten their super tacos on numerous occasions and just tried their torta. Their pork is especially good! I recommend the tacos over anything for a quick bite; however, the spread of Mexican cuisine ranging from seafood soup to whole sea bass is impressive to the eye. I intend to corroborate with my taste buds soon.

Service is good. You can speak in English or Spanish with ease. They have a whole fridge of beer and sodas, beer selection notably acceptable. 

Definitely a must for one craving good Mexican on the go or for mellow gatherings. In addition, could be great drunk food!
author: Max R.

description:
Dude, where are the warning signs?? This thing is ginormous!!

(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RF-ciAQlmV2BO4lVvmfrkg?select=QNfd36kPyFp1Uz6iF5Tpug)

That's a regular size takeout box where the burrito had to be placed sideways since it won't fit otherwise.

Wet burrito: Meat. Beans. Rice. Onions. Cilantro. Salsa. Cheese. Sour cream. Avocado. Enchilada sauce. $6.52. Can you dig it?
author: Marti L.

description: I came here today for lunch and had the carne esada tacos with cilantro and pico de gallo it came with chips. They make the carne esada fresh made to order. They have complimentary water if you don't want to purchase a drink. The staff are friendly and pleasant. You can watch a soccer game while you eat. This is my fifth or sixth time coming here. I highly recommend it for lunch or dinner.
author: Kiana D.

description: This place has the best carne asada burrito! The service is great, and everyone's always so cheerful and friendly!
author: Lisa N.

description: Average at best.   Tried the carne asada super taco, but will try another Mexican place or two before trying this again.
author: Dave C.

description: My food budget usually allows $6 per meal. For $5-something I can get two huge yummy tacos and a small fresh fruit drink, chips, and salsa. This alone gets five stars. But wait, there's more! This is the only place in my neighborhood that regularly has my two favorite items in the entire world: chile rellenos and chicken en mole, both for under $10. Five more stars! There's a salsa bar, Mexican sodas, and usually a soccer game on TV. One of my favorite hangouts.
author: Joseph T.

description:
Ultimate slutty burrito in a non-mission location! These super burritos are massive, oozing goodness like marinated chicken or  carne asada. Salsas are yummy too- great addition. Yes the location is sketch as ever, but honestly why would you buy a slutty burrito from a white guy in the Marina? You have to go to the HOOD to get something this eclectic. 

The guys behind the counter were friendly, there was no line at all. I will definitely be back if I ever want to grab a burrito outside of the mission.
author: Meredith M.

description:
Had some really decent food here. Too bad they overcharged us even though we argued. 

We ordered 3 tacos with meat and 1 super taco and she charged us $14.96!!! Even if she charged us for the chips there is no way we should have been charged 15 bucks. Before you say she charged us the gringo price. My wife is a native spanish speaker and she argued with the lady that each taco should have been $1.99. And the super taco should have been $2.99.  She said something about tax.
Maybe my math is off but that doesn't add up. We didn't feel like arguing for a couple of bucks. Such a shame cause the tacos were actually decent. Too bad they are kinda shady.  Lost our business.
author: Augusto M.

description:
2 stars for being edible (barely) and quick. 

These tacos were a) too big, b) too bland, and c) ugly as hell. I'm sorry for arguing for aestethics but this was straight unappetizing. Colorless carne, flabby tortillas, and even the sauce couldn't save it. 

2 blocks in any other direction, you got a better option.
author: James K.

description: Sometimes when I go there in the morning a little hungover I feel as if they take advantage of my situation by not giving me the super when I ask for the super.  Don't know if I am imagining it or not.
author: Arosh M.

description:
Based on the good reviews on yelp, I thought it would be safe to give this place a try. But, NOPE.

Fair warning -- DO NOT EAT HERE.

I ordered the wet burrito to-go because I was in a rush to get back to work. Disgustingly, when I opened my to-go box, I FOUND A BUG CRAWLING ON MY BURRITO! yuck. Are you serious? GARBAGE. I wasted 10 bucks on a burrito that just ended up in the trash. 

DO NOT COME HERE. ... unless you don't mind eating food that's been crawled on by bugs and such.
author: Jane E.

description:
At first, I didn't have very good feelings about this place, but I've grown to love it. Whenever I'm at  work starving and craving for Mexican food, I automatically think of here. Im a sucker for chicken so I always get a regular burrito with grilled chicken, black beans, salsa, lettuce, and hot sauce. Their burritos aren't super skinny with layers of folded tortilla like you may see at some other places nor are they dry with grains of rice falling onto your lap with every bite.  If you'd like, you get a handfull of tortilla chips tossed into your bag, enough to have a chip with almost every huge bite of deliciousness.  You can also grab a little bit of red or green salsa.

I can't finish a burrito to myself so I always eat half for lunch and the other half for dinner.  My dinner portion is always as tasty as the lunch portion.  Bout 8 bucks for 2 meals, not bad!
There's a good quantity of meats to can choose from and a few different types of tortillas too.  Oh, try the nachos. They pile everything on! 

Lunchtime, Monday thru Friday, the place is always pretty busy from all of the construction workers and the surrounding city workers, but the line moves quite quickly.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
Its finals so... damn it, all I want to eat all day everyday is an al pastor super burrito.

After 10 days of eating my TJ frozen mexican food and trying to pretend it was a substitute, I caved at 10:45 am this morning and got myself an al pastor super burrito. 

You know burrito bliss? Where it feels like you just injected your whole body with some tingly magic? Some people call it love, some people E, some people coke (I certainly DO NOT for the last 2) but I call it burrito. Burrito bliss is a magical thing. 

But the rice was bland, there was too much sour cream, and I made the mistake of getting pinto beans instead of refried beans but the al pastor was delicious, though still a tiny bit bland.  Chips rocked. And the salsa was mild, but good
author: Emily D.

description:
My feelings about El Castillito was that it was pretty average. Lunched here with the siblings. We ended up ordering tacos and burritos.
 The tacos were pretty blegh. The meat was really bland, and don't get me started on the tortilla...ugh I couldn't even it that. My brother ordered chicken tacos and I ordered carne Asada and al pastor. I particularly disliked the tortillas. They were really dry. The meat in the carne Asada taco was pretty good but the marinated pork, aka al pastor, was bland. My brother liked his chicken tacos. The youngest sibling ordered a carnitas super burrito. That was pretty bomb. And it was pretty big. He didn't finish it because he got stuffed. I took a bite and regretted ordering the tacos. Next time I'll def order the burrito. I do think the tacos were over priced.
author: Karin S.

description: Food was ok. I had veg burrito and I had better ones else where. Cash only is definitely drawback. Staff was courteous .
author: Santosh K.

description:
18.2%. That's how much SALES TAX you'll get charged on $7.40 (never mind it was advertised as $7.00) if you're me. Last time I checked, SF sales tax was 8.75%. According to one friend, I was probably given a "special" tax , perhaps because I "had a nice looking coat on" or because I had my $10 bill out and ready to pay (eager to eat as I was).

I ordered a torta listed as $5.85 and got a pepsi for $1.15. Let's check the math -- $7.00. After sales tax, the woman at the register rung me up for $8.75. HUHH? Anyway, I paid it, and as I sat down, did a double take in my head over the transaction that just happened. How did I get taxed almost $2 on a $7 meal, when a coworker that ordered after me was only taxed .82 cents on his $9+ meal? This was not the first time this happened to me here either. This was the second time, and I realized today that the first occurrence was probably not a little one-time slip-up that I should have let happen.

This is how the conversation went with the cash register lady after I went to ask about the "odd" tax on my meal. FYI, I am not the type of person who shouts at people in customer service when I'm upset, so I did this politely:

Me: Excuse me. Can I have a receipt for my order?
Her: Oh no, I don't have any receipts.. heh.
Me: Um, OKAY... well, I'm wondering why I paid $1.75 in tax for my torta and pepsi.
Her: *stares at me* Okay...
Me: My coworker only paid .80 cents in tax for more expensive food, why was my tax almost $2 more?
Her: *shrug and silence*
Me: Is the torta $5.85? *looks up at $5.85 listed price on board*
Her: Uh... no. It's $6.25. So see, you're total was $7.40. Okay?
Me: Well, that's still not right.
Her: I don't know. *awkward look, then looks away*
Me: Fine, okay.

I lost my appetite right away, and my uneaten torta is sitting on my desk. It will be eaten of course (don't waste food, folks) but not anytime soon... I'll probably give it to my boyfriend or my mom. I'm boycotting this place for good, which is really too bad because the food itself isn't that bad.

...But discriminatory taxing and feigned innocence when you're caught leaves a bad taste in my mouth. Make sure you don't get cheated if you come here. So much for a "cheap" lunch.

P.S. If you're wondering why I have so many check-ins to this business, the other times I was accompanying my coworker to pick up something and not purchasing anything myself. Otherwise I'd have a hell of a lot less check-ins.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Matt took his new co-worker here for lunch. He's only been in SF for only 2 weeks and he never ate at a SF Taqueria. He likes Mexican food and Matt, who has eaten here a couple of times, will introduce this place to him

We were here at around 12:30, and the line wasn't too bad with 5 "HUNGRY" people ahead of us. The line moved at a steady pace. The worker gave us some fresh chips and salsa. Surprisingly, there were plenty of seats in the dining area during lunchtime.

Matt ordered a Carne Asada Quesadillia Suiza and a can of Sunkist for $5.75 total for the meal. The Quesadillia was very oily, but the meat was tasty and wasn't burnt like other taquerias. Co-worker ordered the Carnitas regular burrito. Considerring it is JUST a regular burrito, it is a pretty good size, and the Pork, likewise wasn't burnt, but was very tasty. His meal, including a Coke was a tad over $6.00.

Co-worker's first taqueria in SF, wasn't a disappointing one. He is definitely coming back, but Matt still needs to show him the Mission District.
author: Matt G.

description: Super burrito, chips n salsa, and a negra.  This will put you in a food coma. Fast service at a good price = successful burrito spot.
author: John B.

description: Consistently delicious tacos!!! Pastor and carne asada are seasoned on point. Wayyyy Better than the popular taco joints that are reviewed in magazines or tv shows that were rated best in SFO. Green, red  and roasted chilli, pickled jalapenos, and salsa are some of the condiments available for your liking "pick your own style."
author: Karl S.

description: One of the better burritos that I've ever had. And I've had a lot of burritos. The chips were just OK, the salsa was good, but the chicken and cheese in the burrito were very nearly perfect. Definitely a hidden gem. I am glad The Hall was closed tonight domain could not only eat a tastier meal, but I saved at least $5. Delicious!
author: Curtis F.

description:
I'm definitely a fan but I don't find myself going out of my way to go here when there are better places relatively close for about 2 dollars less. You more or less can get a comparable (if not better) burrito in the neighborhood  for cheaper.

Trust me, I'm not taking anything away from this place but why not go to a place right down the street for the same thing and cheaper.

The burrito was huge though and delicious...
author: Sean D.

description:
This place fit all my criteria on finding great Mexican food:
-Great reviews on Yelp
-In a somewhat shady area
-specialized in wet burritos

I was duped. Average at best...I wouldn't go out of your way to come here.
author: Jeff F.

description: It's a hole-in-the-wall spot but the service is friendly and the portions huge. I had a prawn burrito - ironically I liked everything but the prawns. I would go back and try a different meat. It was really filling.
author: Jam Rockah E.

description: Authentic, at least by my gringo standards. Fish and chicken tacos fabulous. Seriously, two takedowns by police on our walk to this place. Neighborhood can be dicey but worth the risk!
author: Joe M.

description:
This was everything everyone else says. It's cheap, clean, and an extremely good value. I would have taken a star away because there's no salsa bar, but the free chips and the green tomatillo/avocado salsa was good enough to make up for it. But I did miss various different kinds of salsa and the lime chunks.

Although there's no official table service, the lady at the counter was not busy when I came in so she came over to my table and opened my Mexican Coke for me. I used the SF Weekly deal to get a carnitas wet burrito and a to-go carnitas. She gave me the wet burrito and I said to her when two other customers came in, "I don't mind if you take care of them and get me my to-go burrito later." So she brought it over to my table.

My carnitas wet burrito was flavorful. The steak was very well marinated and tender with just a little bit of fat and gristle. The portion size was very generous.

The little serving trays for the chips are on the small size, but I've worked in the restaurant business, and I know if you give a big serving tray, people fill them and waste a lot. So I didn't mind going back eight or nine times for refills. But because of the sketchy Tenderloin residents who were there with me, I had to keep an eye on my bag so no one would grab my Macbook in my shoulder bag and run.

But no one made a move for it.

Ordinarily when someone only takes my order and hands it to me I usually only give one buck. But she was so friendly and didn't give me a look because I used the coupon, I came back at the end and put another buck in her cup. She was friendly and charming.
author: Kenn F.

description:
In an area dominated by the best Vietnamese food in SF, El Castillito is a force to be reckoned with. It's like the "little Mexican restaurant" that could, pumping out DELICIOUS Mexican food in the T-Loin. It's gotten Lael A.'s stamp of approval and that means alot coming from a born & raised San Diegan who claims to have never had a burrito in SF that can hold a candle to those in Oceanside.... until El Castillito.

I'm a regular here so I've tried a bunch of different things, but here are the standouts:

-Chicken Asada Super Burrito: I don't ever order chicken asada burritos. When we visit my boyfriend's parents in SD, I'm typically a "carne asada" kind of girl. But this is one of the best burritos I've ever had. Hands down, the best Chicken Asada burrito I've ever had. The chicken is soooo tender, juicy and flavorful. And El Castillito serves up some damn good rice. Combined with creamy sour cream and avocado, this burrito hits every note: savory, creamy, spicy. Please try this and leave me a compliment when you're blown away by how good the Chicken Asada Super Burrito is. 

-Aguas Frescas: My boyfriend and I split a large size and kill it with no problem. Delightfully sweet and fresh, its the ultimate compliment to the food here. My favorite is the Canteloupe.

If you're a pork fan, the el pastor and carnitas are also very good. Pass on the carne asada. The chicken and pork are the stars here. 

Tip: CASH ONLY!
author: Monelle A.

description: Quesadillas con pollo are a bit dry. However, the quantity is very decent.
author: R G.

description: This place is now my go-to when I want delicious, inexpensive Mexican food.  I ordered the two-taco plate with chicken and black beans.  I love that they have a black beans available, and I got a lot of chicken in the tacos, all for around $7-$8.  I'm not sure if they charged me a bag fee though.  I'll have to ask next time I go.
author: Vira P.

description:
Being from Mexican descent and having tried a lot of Mexican food, I take it seriously recommending a Mexican restaurant (Ok, not THAT seriously). But I have to write this place a review because I keep coming back.
The choice and quality of different meats is great. I LOVE the chicken in red broth. The steak is always great. 
The best about this place is the rice and the different beans - it really makes a huge difference to me. 
The staff is very friendly, fast and generous. The prices are very good.
The only negative has to be the chips that they serve. They are store-bought and not that good. But they make up for it with everything else.
Definitely my go-to mexican place outside of the Mission..
author: Carlos V.

description:
People who grew up in Southern California have had the luxury of being spoiled with arguably the best Mexican food in the United States. Carne asada fries. Burritos filed with moist chunks of meat, guacamole, and salsa sans beans and rice. Fish tacos. The list goes on and on and on. Talk to a Southern California transplant living in San Francisco, and you'll probably hear, "[Insert hole in the wall taco shop located in Southern California] has the [Insert any Mexican food item] ever. Mexican food in [Insert San Francisco] sucks."

I've been to many, many, many different hole in the wall Mexican restaurants throughout the Bay Area. Mexican food in Southern California still reigns supreme. There is just no denying it. However, there are some places in San Francisco that I've grown to like because, well, it's hard to get a burrito from down south when you live up here. 

El Castillito satisfies my craving for Mexican food. They have the best pollo asado burrito I've had thus far in San Francisco. The chunks of dark chicken meat are moist and seasoned well. Against my better burrito judgment, I've even become accustomed to including rice in the burrito because El Castillito's rice is delicious. Don't forget to wash this down with one of their freshly made aguas frescas - watermelon and cantaloupe are so so refreshing. I've also had the el pastor and carnitas tacos, which are also tasty. I was disappointed with their carne asada and chorizo breakfast burrito, but their other items more than make up for it. 

Make sure you come with an empty stomach or prepare to take this bad boy home. The burritos here are BIG. 

I also love the staff at El Castillito. Without fail, I always have this exchange everytime I order a burrito:

Me:      Rice, but no beans
Them:  Extra beans?
Me:      No, just rice please - thanks. Hahahah
Them:  Extra beans?
author: Lael A.

description:
This is my first eating out experience near school, and it was definitely a very good one. I got the wet burrito and it comes with a burrito covered in mole, cheese, sour cream, and avocado. Normally I don't finish whole burritos because it gets boring and dry after awhile, but this one definitely entertained to the end.

I haven't tried any of their items as this was my first visit, but I trust them enough to want other things on the menu now. But still keep in mind that it's the tenderloin so the ambiance and atmosphere might not be ideal. But the portions are generous, the prices are good, and the food is definitely quality.
author: Maureen C.

description: Solid taqueria in a not so good part of town. The carne asada burrito is delicious and quite filling and the enchilada plate is also very good. The watermelon aqua fresca wasn't as sweet as I was hoping for, but passable. Service is pretty fast and the guys behind the counter are very friendly. In an area without a lot of good Mexican options, this is a solid bet if you're in the neighborhood and craving a burrito.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Had two tacos. One super with chicken and one regular with carne asada. Both pretty tasty but nothing that blew me out of the water. Was a good sized-portion and kept me full for the rest of the work day. Fresh avocado and sour cream on the super taco but the pico on both tacos wasn't the freshest and didn't have enough lime in it. Otherwise pretty good for the area. I liked their chips and salsa verde, which are available at the counter. The chips seemed to have some grain in it, not just corn tortilla chips. The salsa verde had just the right amount of spice. Would come back here just because of it's proximity to work. Prices are OK, could be cheaper.

Cash only.
author: Sannie L.

description: Awesome vegetarian enchilada! Had some at an event and it was fab. In addition to their enchiladas are the salsas and chips. Some of the best I've ever had. In addition, this taqueria also supports charity so its not just for profit.
author: R C.

description: Love love love this place! AND they accept plastic = 100 times more dangerous. I come here at least once per week.
author: Alex W.

description:
One of the cleanest taquerias in town! And Cesar is so friendly and customer-focused that it makes the food taste even better! At Cesar's recommendation, I chose their pollo en salsa verde for the quesadilla Castillito with the works including some beautiful jalapenos! 

The carne asada plate was beautifully cooked and smelled soo good! From the fresh pico de gallo to the beans, rice and the carne, everything was seasoned nicely for full impactful flavor!

BUT what REALLY set this little gem apart from other taquerias, for me, is the fact that you see a crate of fresh tomatillos behind the counter ready to be peeled and made into the FRESHEST salsa ever! Hearty crispy chips too!! Stop by and you I don't think you'll be disappointed!
author: Carmen M.

description:
Juicy super burrito! 

Chips look like they are whole grain and they fill me up!
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Get the castillito quesadilla for the best bang for your buck. I love that they stock Mexican sodas (including coke!) that are cheap and cool. Those are some tasty suckers. 

The ingredients are fresh and they give generous portions of avocado in the quesadilla, and it tastes very authentic and filling. They also give chips and there is a decent selection of salsas from the salsa bar. 

Service is very good here, the woman running the shop is very friendly. They accept credit cards here, which is a godsend for someone like me who never carries cash (I hate cash). Prices are cheap and reasonable, and they play sports here on the TV.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I was really impressed with the carne asada.  I wanted to go back for more, but I wasn't going to adventure into the tenderloin after dark.  The super burrito was great and the tacos were ridiculously good.  The salsa really makes the food here- dump it on anything and you'll be in heaven.  I loved the salsa bar with it's delish salsas, whole roasted peppers, and fresh radishes.  You go, El Castillito! 

The only thing I didn't like was the carnitas.  Too dry while at the same time being overly greasy.
author: Jordan F.

description:
I come here for the burritos and not the atmosphere. 

This is either a love it or hate it kinda joint. I love it for the burritos. But I get mine to go. Overall I am not a big fan of the location or hanging out to eat here, which is why the overall rating is 3 stars. Service is typically middle of the road as well.

But the thing I love is those big, fat burritos that easily make two meals for the day. I will happily trot down here and pick up two to last me a couple days. Well worth the trip.
author: Nick B.

description:
Discovering this place has probably not been good for my wallet, as I've been coming here quite often. I work on Van Ness a short walk away, and El Castillito has quickly become my main go-to place when on my lunch break.

Although it's in a pretty sketchy area of the TL, El Castillito is a pretty good Mexican joint if you're craving a burrito or a torta. It's spacious enough if you and some friends have time to sit down for a meal, and I've never seen more than 5-6 people in there during the evenings (I tend to drop by between 4P~6P). The staff here is gracious enough and pretty laid back. They've miffed the occasional order due to not paying attention, but never to the point where it grew annoying. Refried beans instead of black? Whatever, it's cool, man.

The food itself is good, and I've never had a bad experience in that regard. It seems slightly pricey compared to some of the other places I go to, but that may be because it's so close to the Federal building and the courthouse - taking advantage of those government types who need their Mexican fixings. Proportionally, the amount you get is alright for the price; it's difficult to finish an entire super burrito which is in the area of $6.

Overall I've never found a reason not to come back to El Castillito, at least on work days when I'm in the area. There aren't many decent, cheap places to eat in the area, and this is one of the very few. Good for a quick eat or a sit-down meal, if you've got a craving for a burrito in the TL this place is as good as any I've seen so far.

PS: CASH ONLY. But if you've got Bank of America or Wells Fargo there are ATMs literally right next to the place.
author: Will C.

description:
I love that some of the cheapest places in San Francisco have the most to offer in terms of deliciousness.  A friend recommended this spot, so I'd figure why not?  The best way to describe this place is cozy, modest, and flavorful.

I ordered the Super Burrito which comes with rice, beans, onions, cilantro, cheese, avocado, sour cream, and your choice of meat.  I went straight for the carne asada.  Other possibilities include pastor, regular pollo, pollo asado, chorizo, lengua (beef tongue), carnitas, pollo en salsa verde, and cabeza (beef head).  As I saw the line cook construct this burrito behemoth, I couldn't help but stand back in awe... and drool.

The burrito itself only costs $6.43 which is a pretty sweet deal considering the fact that I was only able to eat half of it before sitting back in defeat.  I was literally satiated until the next day.  

Some tips:
1. If you plan to get a drink, I'd either recommend the Mexican soda or fresh fruit drinks that are made with an actual juicer.

2. This restaurant is conveniently located close to the Asian Art Museum.  If you plan on going there, I'd say skip to overpriced sandwiches at their cafe and head on over here to get some major munch on.

3. Have a ziploc bag, tupperware, or a giant purse (that you wouldn't mind smelling like a burrito all day) handy.  Seriously... you'll have left overs.  I was sad when I had leave my burrito behind.  I don't want you to make the same mistake.
author: Xuan T.

description:
Yes. This place is perfect. Cheap. Delish. Near my job in the hood where there's lot of good cheap food. 

Prawn tacos. CASH ONLY.
author: Parichehr M.

description:
There are two camps of thought when it comes this burrito place -- either you love it or you hate it.  When you live in the Tenderloin, or go to school at Hastings, your food opens are limited, either it's the "burrito place on Golden Gate" (this one) or the "burrito place on McAllister" (the other one).  Many of my friends love this place.  They say that the burritos are huge and delicious.  They also have some unique selections such as lengua (tongue).

I, on the other hand, have never been impressed by this place.  The walk to get there is unpleasant.  The inside does not seem to clean, and it's uncomfortable to sit through a meal there.  I always find the meat dry and too salty.  I feel like they over salt the meat because it is not fresh, and they don't want it to go bad.  It never looks to clean to me, so I'm always afraid that I'll get food poisoning from the veggies.  I proceed with caution to say the least.  I prefer a more carefree burrito experience because I do enjoy eating.  It stressful to calculate my risk as I make each selection.  

With all that effort, I just go to the one on McAllister.  The meat is freshier and not dried out from salt, the company is less sketchy.
author: Sue N.

description: I need to correct my review. I confused this shop with the one down the block. I like this one way better! Especially their aqua fresca!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Chorizo breakfast burrito + Mexican Coca-Cola = euphoria. 

Staff is nice. Location is cool, right near the U.N.
author: Federico E.

description: Great taqueria in the heart of the TL. The carne asada burrito here is one of the best I've had in the City. The al pastor tacos are also very good. Friendly staff working there.
author: Nick R.

description:
I've heard this is a sister store to El Castillito "B" on McAllister.  Either way, skip the McAllister one and come here!  This is a worthwhile competitor to the Subway across the street.  

I only get carne asada burrito because it's gooood.  Ask them to put their green avocado/tomatillo sauce in there for extra flavor.  

Generous handful of tortilla chips (I hate stinginess) rounds out a burrito meal that is perfect for any starving student.
author: C L.

description: Freaking huge delicious burritos! And bomb agua fresca, get the strawberry one. Mind blowing! Definitely a go to taqueria in the Mission.
author: Moni E.

description:
That was one of the best chicken in red sauce tacos I've ever had. All white meat and plenty of it. Mild and tasty sauce. Packed to the brim with onions and cilantro.

Fifth star earned with the price. An unbelievable $0.99. It might have been a special, but even at the regular menu price of $2.50 it's still a steal.

Who knew Mexican in the 'loin could be so good?
author: Jason B.

description:
It's hard to screw up tacos and burritos. Add meat and cheese to a tortilla and you ahve something tasty. However, the flavors El Castillito put into some of their meats make them a bit above the rest. 

The green chile chicken has a nice slow heat coupled with a deliciuos flavor. You can choose from whole or refried pinto beans. Then there's the usual rice, sour cream, avocado, salsa. The service is minimal because it is a tacqueria after all, but the cook was very tolerant and friendly with me and my bizzare order (no rice, no onions, extra cilantro, pico de gallo (even though i said no onions). The prices are fair. The soda selection is surprisingly large for this small of a place. It was a great place to pick up a quick bite!
author: Kat S.

description:
I love this taqueria, better than the El Castillito on the next block.  You would think they are the same business, but they aren't.  This one seems to be linked to the El Castillito on Church Street.

I love their al pastor, carne asada, and marinated chicken.  Veggie burritos are good, super quesadillas are messy but awesome, and the $.99 tacos are the best deal around.

Service is friendly, salsa bar is great, and they show World Cup games.  Awesome!
author: Joseph N.

description: Had the Burrito with carne asada and the beef wasnt good at all. Also no complementary chips. I think I won't come back
author: Hans C.

description:
Huge veggie burrito + cold beer = $8 

How awesome is that!!! Totally check this place out. The burrito was grande and filling. Pretty good quality and very tasty.

Skip the chips and salsa since they aren't great and save the room for the rest.
author: J. S.

description:
First the pluses:
Had one of their burritos and it was delicious.  Meat was moist and tender, the super burrito also comes with sour cream and avacado.  Big chunks of the fresh stuff.  Price was good too.

Then the Mehs:
I have a certain "thing" about aqua frescas.  It's great that they have them, but the selection is limited to two.  I was in a hurry so I didn't even order one this time around, but will definitely try next time.

Finally ...:
Most other places I've been to have a good size salsa bar with different kinds of salsas for chips and such.  Didn't see that here.  Maybe it's around and I just didn't see it?

Regardless, will be back to try other things.
author: Winnie C.

description:
My new obsession: tortas.  

It has everything: avocado, sour cream, cheese, meat, lettuce, tomato.  Grilled cheese.  Did I mention cheese?  There is a hollowed out little pocket in the inside of the top half of the roll.  That man stuffed it with that burrito cheese and then GRILLED it.  

When I held it between my hands, I could feel the slippery, smooth happiness compressed into carbohydrate form.  I thought I was trying to catch stars with my baseball cap.  The endless appeal of the flavors was better than a burrito.  Better than a quesadilla.  The bread was flaky like an effing croissant.  

Cheese, grilled into a croissant, filled with avocado, meat, sour cream, lettuce and tomato.  Top it off with hot salsa, and I will forsake king and country.  For 2 days.  

It is the best cure for insomnia.  That food coma will hit you like a greek god who gave birth through his forehead.  

And it was $4.90.
author: Christina C.

description: Cheap and delicious.  Authentic Mexican food with a warm atmosphere.  I had the super burrito with cartos meat and everything included and nothing was left after I was finished.  Now I'm just a 15 year old adolescent but I highly recommend this place if you have Mexican cuisine on your mind.  Adios
author: Augie H.

description:
The Quesadillas here are sooooooooooooo good and they are HUGE too! love it love it love it!!! :)

This place gets pretty busy during lunch hour, but the workers here are pretty on top on things. The place can be a tad cleaner, but what can you expect in TL right?
author: M W.

description:
Good, solid burrito. 

Super steak burrito with hot sauce. It's gigantic, greasy, and so good! The tacos are just as great.

The lady that rings us up is really sweet. The guys that artfully craft our burritos are funny. They like to crack jokes and tease. There used to be one guy, a taller, clean cut fellow, that was great. He knew our orders and stuffed our burritos full. 

This is the only place I'd go to for burritos. After eatting here, all other burritos suck. 

Beware of long lunch lines. The people who work around here form long lines between noon and around 1:30. Go in before or a little after.
author: Jeanette P.

description:
Still the best burrito in town.  The 2 for one coupons in SF weekly make it the best deal.  They have actually started making the burritos fatter and reducing the grease.  Also, I tried out their nachos and they are superb.

Don't forget to load up on the green sauce.  I'd avoid the raw radishes, but that goes for any restaurant.
author: Joey S.

description: Do you like authentic San Francisco Style Super Burritos? Do you like meat and beans? Well this place has got all that and a bag a chips. I had their wet burrito yesterday and it was simply wetlicious. Bigger than my head but the taste goes straight to my heart. Fresh ingredients, some fatty meat pieces but why I called it authentic. No Marina burrito here son, it's only the best burrito this side of SF. Will go there again to try their fresh squeezed juices.
author: Kato D.

description: I eat here a lot! I love the El Pastor burritos and the Camarones al mojo de ajo. Also the service is great when you're regular because you can whisper your order to the guy that knows you and by the time you get up to pay it's ready!
author: Mira L.

description: We had the wet burrito.  Huge portions and nice service.  The chips that they serve weren't the best (and they heated our burrito in the microwave).  However, the burrito was spicy with tasty toppings.
author: Mac P.

description:
THIS LITTLE PIGGY....

This little piggy went to EL CASTILLITO, 
This litttle piggy liked her GARGATUAN RICE AND BEANS BURRITO,
This little piggy almost finished her yummy lunch,
And then this little piggy cried,
"OW, OW, OW."
All the way home.

(I had a stomachache for being such a  piggy.")

$5.12 for rice and bean burrito with extra avocado (without is $3.69). Extensive taqueria menu. Fresh Ingredients. Packed and chilled salsa ready for "grab and go". Delicious and cheap Mexican food in the TL serving huge portions. 

Just in case you were wondering, here's the ORIGINAL NURSERY RHYME version:

This little piggy went to market. 
This little piggy stayed at home. 
This little piggy has roast beef, 
This little piggy had none. 
And this little piggy cried "Wee! Wee! Wee!" 
All the way home

REMEMBER THIS FROM NURSERY SCHOOL?:)
author: Leah E.

description:
I really had ulterior motives with my torta order.  Being hungover to a degree where my dehydrated body was aching for grease, but not to the point where I was too disgusted to eat, felt myself veering into that zone where post-drinking day self-loathing leads me on a gluttonous bender.  I knew KNEW if I got a burrito I would repeat the 'just half' mantra, only to eat the entire thing & continue the vicious cycle to now include a day of bad eating in addition to events of the night prior.

So, anywho, I was like, order a torta & thwart fate.  Turned out to be the best decision of my weekend!  It was wicked delicious - carne burnt ends goodness, extra salty cheese melted into a chewy bun, creamy & totally evenly spread out sour cream, fresh tomato, fresh avocado.  I ate the entire thing, was full but in no way stuffed or guilt ridden & my hangover was sufficiently greased without having a little 5lb rice/bean/tortilla baby in my stomach all day.  Huzzah!
author: Talia R.

description:
Por que son dos Castillitos on Golden Gate? THIS ONE IS WAAAAAAY BETTER!!!
The al pastor is good, but sometimes it seems they aren't busy enough to keep it super fresh, just decent fresh. The salsa verde is right on.  DO NOT GO to the one closer to Larkin.  I don't know what the Castillito owners are up to, but they should close that other one down and keep this one, it's as good as the one on Church.
Considering the lack of good mexican in this 'hood, this place is better than expected! yay!
author: N. L.

description:
A tiny burrito place - perfect for lunch. 

They have their system down pat - so the line moves fast.

The carintas were very good and the burrito overall was good - but lacked a little kick/flavor - I added some hot sauce and it was great!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Has this place closed?

I walked by this restaurant the other day and it was dark.  Tables were stacked and there were bags of cement lying around.  No sign on the door indicating whether the owners had shut the restaurant down.  Could be that they were remodeling, but the lack of a sign is troubling.
author: Bruce I.

description:
I almost didn't make it in to El Castillito.  Even though I had Yelped the place and seen the excellent reviews, El Castillito has the misfortune of being about two doors down from Morty's Deli, one of the best sandwich spots in The City.

There I was, out on the sidewalk on Golden Gate Avenue, walking back and forth endlessly between Morty's and El Castillito, peering into the windows indecisively and probably looking very much like one of the "colorful characters" who tend to populate that particular block of the Tenderloin.

FINALLY after much consternation I decided to be bold and try El Castillito, the unknown quantity.  Once inside I knew it was gonna be alright.  Employees all Mexican: Check.  Virgin of Guadalupe shrine in the corner:  Check.  TV on the wall tuned to Mexican Soap Opera: Check.  Gorged myself on a fat Breakfast Burrito loaded with Chorizo and washed down with Jarritos soda and life was beautiful.

Prices are dirt cheap (they even have a 99 cent Taco special) but the place is very clean.

If I can continue to resist the pull of Morty's I will DEFINITELY be back!
author: Mike J.

description:
Te quiero, Castillito...

I remember this place back in the day when it was Fiesta Taco, yup, we go way back. 

I cannot go more than a couple weeks without one of their veggie burritos.  I have converted a wide variety of food snobs to El Castillito fans.

The guys who work here are super nice and will remember you if you've come in a few times.  They let me rock out to Selena on the jukebox, though I know they must not be too pleased with me blasting the same 2 songs every time I'm in there.

The neighborhood is disgusting, which, so long as you are safe inside, can be entertaining.  A friend and I saw a guy wrestle with the police and get thrown into the back of their paddy wagon, at one point he face was smashed against the window literally 18" away from us.  That's what I call dinner and a show.

But seriously, this place rocks and their carnitas tacos are what most people I know get.  I can't veer away from my veggie burrito, which is enhanced to ambrosia when I top it with the delicious green salsa.
author: Lindsey H.

description: I love this place - this is the go to place for those working in the TL so remember that when you show up at noon.  The line will be long but it moves fast and is worth the wait.  I always feel that rice and beans tell the story and theirs doesn't disappoint.  The prices are reasonable and you will not leave hungry.  Don't want to forget the staff - friendliest hard working group around.  You all rock!!
author: Patti L.

description:
Great mexican joint... The burritos are huge.. my favorite is the Al Pastor WET burrito.
Lady there is really nice.
Quick, filling and heavy... great when you feel like you're starving!
author: Christian P.

description:
I went to El Castillito about a month ago with the boyfriend (again, yes, as this is our burrito-Mecca) and was about to order a wet burrito when I saw a charming Chicano ordering a number of tortas with carne asada.  

Oh.UhMay.HuGawd.  

It smelled *so* good!  You see, it's a torta- a sandwich with meat and veggies and avocado and salsa and sour cream...  But wait! There's more!  They make this well in the top part of the bread and put the cheese in it and then GRILL IT.  Yes, they grill the cheese before putting it on grilled meats and veggies and things.

Wet Burrito, I loved you. I was a little freaked out at your appearance, but I loved you.  Note the past tense, though, you beautiful burrito.  I have a new food obsession, and that is Torta, King of Sandwiches.
author: Kate K.

description: This taqueria is close to my job and when I feel a craving for something Mexican, I come here for a take out lunch.  Each time I come in here, there is always a line of people, which means great food and great prices, despite the area - the Tenderloin.  The prices are pretty reasonable and the portions are generous.  The veggie tacos are great and quite delish that I have gone back twice this week to eat them - corn tortillas on the grill, melted shredded cheese, rice, whole pinto beans with toppings of shredded lettuce, chopped tomatoes, cilantro, sour cream and fresh avocado...yummy.  I also had eaten their prawn burrito, which was humongous and had, I believe, at least 10 pieces of prawns.  After having eaten half of the burrito and having a full stomach...it was time for a siesta/power nap.  (Thank goodness, my boss didn't tell me "no sleeping on the job"...lol.)  Also, there is a large variety of cold beverages (in the refrigerators), but nothing tops off these items than a glass of agua fresca - always refreshing and flavorful.
author: Carol C.

description:
Unfortunately they were out of al pastor when I got there late at night, so instead I got chorizo, carne asada, and carnitas tacos.  They were all delicious and I can't wait to go back and try their al pastor.

I also had the fresh squeezed orange juice.  It's pricey, but sooo good!
author: Sushant P.

description:
Ordered a carne asada super burrito and a super vegetarian burrito.  

The carne asada one was good--nice and filled to the brim with stuff and excellently rolled.  I have had better elsewhere but it definitely hit the spot.  The super vegetarian was too spicy for my better half.  He picked out a couple of whole jalapenos in his burrito which is no bueno.

I will probably be back for more.  Maybe I'll try the torta that many reviewers are raving about!
author: Tysen C.

description:
Finally, a reason not to shoot myself. I used to work in Duboce Park, smack dab in the middle of a bevy of outstanding lunch options, which being the ungrateful spoiled brat I am, I never truly appreciated until I was re-located to the Civic Center area, which by the way, has basically nothing for food, especially if you are a live to eat type (aka: total glutton who should probably be re-channeling the energy you take into picking meals into something productive, like say, writing a novel or volunteering or you know, anything remotely useful to the world or another human being). Sure, if you are the type who is okay with eating the same boring turkey and wheat sandwich or McDonald's for lunch every single day, you will do fine in the Civ Center. Not me. 

So, today, after experiencing an all consuming LUST for a super burrito, I walked down Larkin to this Little Castle, expecting the same old rigamorale I get at the Church St location, which I go to pretty frequently. However, I was greeted by several differences, which have earned it the 5th star: avocado instead of guacamole (score!), no lettuce in the super burrito (awesome, who wants lettuce in a burrito) and much nicer, non-skeevy dudes working behind the counter. Being eye raped doesn't really add to the experience for me. Maybe it does for you.
author: Maria D.

description:
I have to reaffirm my love of El Catillito. I work down the block so have been having lunch here an average of once a week for almost 3 years. I LOVE this place. I haven't tried every burrito joint in the Mission, but this place is certainly better than the ones I have tried. 

The food is absolutely fresh and fabulous, and it meets my number one criterion for a good Mexican place, which is to serve fresh avocado instead of guacamole. Today, rather than my usual carnitas, I decided to try the burrito de camarones, which precipitated this updated love of El Castillito. 

My only beef (er, carnita?) is that they don't have mini or small burritos. I always intend on eating only half, but always, always eat the whole damn thing and then feel like I can't eat another thing for 2 days....
author: Amy B.

description:
When they let Shatangi order in Spanish, fuhgetaboudit!!!  Best carne asada EV-AR. I can never finish the super. It's like football sized. Fast, efficient and friendly service and great fresh chips and salsas.

Shatangi te dijo...
author: Njon W.

description:
I almost wet myself when I discovered there was ANOTHER El Castillito.  (The primary el Castillito is, of course, on Church).

The good: they are down with the sickness -- they've got that delicious green ambrosia -- salsa verde.

The ok: the vegetarian burrito is large, wrapped in a single piece of tinfoil and gets the job done with all of the required fixin's.

The bad: the best part of the Church Street Castillito is notably absent from the Golden Gate Castillito-- the vegetarian quesadilla.  For 5 bucks at Church street you get the best quesadilla cum burrito you've ever set eyes on -- complete with jalapeos.

Not bad and NOT to be confused with El Castillo, a mediocre Mexican place, a block away.
author: jack p.

description:
We were in the area for Dr Katz at the Herbst Theater. We were hoping to go to Saigon Sandwiches, but no dice, they were closed. So we checked this place out.

The staff was pretty nice. The neighborhood is as bad as you'd expect. The place is as bare bones as you can get. The veggie burrito was good, but not excellent. 

It served its purpose.
author: Emily M.

description:
If you crave burritos on the reg, you know that a solid san francisco slab needs several perfectly congruent elements in order to make a lasting impression.  I don't know what it is about El Castillito - at first glance, I thought it was the insanely addicting tomatillo salsa verde.  But after a few dozen trips to the Little Castle, I realized that something else separates this Tenderloin staple from the rest of San Francisco's hole-in-the-wall taquerias, and it goes by the name of intangibility.  

I've been going to school around the corner for nearly three years, and not a week goes by that I don't dodge a crack-head, witness a drug deal and speed walk my way over to the ironically named "Little" Castle for a gargantuan slab of Mexi heaven.  The ingredient mix is unspoiled, and watching the near flawless wrap construction is its own enchanting experience.  With that said, virtually every Castillito Super Burrito is a slam dunk.  I usually opt for either the Super Veggie (I'm telling you, there's something magical in that rice) or, when I feel like passing out in the law library in full blown burrito comatose for a few hours, the Super Carne Asada.  Little Castle is a little bit of paradise.
author: Korey A.

description:
So, so good.  Too good.  So good is the pastor super burrito that I have sworn off the pastor super burrito until further notice.  I tried to exercise restraint and limit myself to eating only half, but that didn't work out so well.

Tasty, cheap, and the service is super-fast, so don't be intimidated by the line out the door.
author: Daryl E.

description:
So I guess this is the best burrito in the Tenderloin, but nothing special at all.

I was expecting 'something' based on a bunch of glowing reviews. Alas, I was led astray. 

This thing was so average, it was shocking. 

Girth? Indeed, but not much else. 

The rice lacked taste, and even making it super couldn't save this thing from mediocrity. 

The capper: it cost 7 bucks.
author: Jason R.

description: Had the Alambre here and tried some of a friend's prawn burrito.  Both were filling and flavorful, but the prawn burrito was best--delicately spiced, the shrimp very fresh, the sauce complimentary.  My Alambre was a little bacon heavy (don't get me wrong, I love bacon, but this was more bacon than beef) but all the ingredients (avocado, peppers, lettuce, pico de gallo, etc) were clearly fresh and tasty.  The tortillas were fragrant and fresh and delicious. The cook and gal at the counter were both very friendly and the food was pretty darn cheap for San Francisco.  The only thing I could think they could improve is the salsa.  It could have a little more depth of flavor and could definitely be spicier.  But I like my face to melt off when I eat spicy food and I know that's just me.
author: DS M.

description:
Burrito in TL?  yeah, it sounds pretty bad but then again, some of the best pho and other cheapo foods are the best here in Little Saigon.  

and as odd it may be to have a burrito joint, probably the only one, seeing that this is NOT the Mission, this is actually a really good place.  I'm starting to think that all mexican joints are good.  (ok no, scratch that, there are some pretty horrible ones)

And if you're worried about cleanliness, its somewhat comforting to know that most of the city health officials right by the Dpt of Public Health work just 2 blocks down.

BUT onto the food!  On one of my lunch breaks, i decided to get a super burrito with Lengua and everything.   That 5 lb 2 foot whatchamacallit was gigantic and i decided there was no way i could finish it.  Lengua (beef tongue) was awesome.  If you like regular beef, but would rather have something a slight bit softer and maybe chewier, this is a must.  They are also very generous with the sauce as i like my burritos moist on the inside.  And so, i went to my friend's spot to share my burrito.  Little did I know that they would not answer the door!  and in the end, I ate the whole darn thing on my own.  PTFO on my seat in the office.  THANKS El Castillito!  but yes, this place is the bomb!  AND they give you a side of chips.  all for under $7
author: Vincent K.

description:
It's hard for me to stray from Taqueria Cancun...but after studying at the library a few weeks ago, and being in the TL already, I came here...what a beacon!

It is pretty standard run-of-the-mill taqueria and for that it should only get like three stars, but what gives it four for me was their al pastor (pork with onions and such)...it is really really good.  And, because it was so good, I nursed my hangover on New Year's Day with a super burrito chock-full of the stuff!  :) Great place, nice staff, and very accomodating.
author: Kristin E.

description:
The most interesting thing to note at this place is that you can order an ALL MEAT burrito for just about a buck more than a regular burrito.  MMMM all meat!

I wussed out however and tried a regular carne asada, but I was pretty impressed.  The ingredients really meshed well, and there wasn't an overabundance of anything (I can't stand places that give you Rice Bombs!!!) .

As with most taquerias, the burrito is too friggin big.  I made it just past half and I was stuffed.  It's a shame they don't reheat a little better.

Looking forward to ordering an all meat burrito next time.  If it shapes up, it could be the closest thing to a San Diego burrito anywhere north of Carlsbad.
author: Rocco B.

description:
NOTE:  I'M ACTUALLY REVIEWING THE CHURCH STREET LOCATION.  THIS IS MY SECOND YELP REVIEW. I'M A DORK. GET OVER IT.....carry on

Cheap, greasy chicken tacos served with salsa and diced onions (the way they should be)  + 2Points

Awesome & funny grill guys who seem to really mean it when they call you "amigo".  + 2Points

I really like their Quesadilla Castillito too.  Nuthin like some pickled jalapenos, greasy chicken, gobs of sour cream and fresh avocado (you have to ask for it) wrapped in a gooey-ooey, cheesy tortilla (I think I just wet myself).

Their Huevos Rancheros are pretty good too if you are looking for carbs, carbs, carbs!!
author: Antonio L.

description:
La Taqueria El Castillito is a great place for a burrito. This might be one of the best burrito places in the city..... I like their Super Burritos. They hook you up with everything. You get rice, sour cream, beans, cheese, and whatever type of meat you would like. I highly recommend getting the grilled chicken super burritos. Even though these burritos are obviously pretty feeling, they're good! The burriros are a reasonable price, around $6or so.

I also love their super nachos as well. They hook you up with these as well. These super nachos are too much for one person and I normally end up sharing these nachos with a couple of my friends. The super nachos are kind of expensive, even if you get extra meat. It goes for around $11or so. Even though they are expensive, it's worth it.

Another thing I like about this place is the service. The service is great and as I said, they hook you up! I highly recommend this place.
author: Otis B.

description:
Burritos, burritos, and more burritos... I recently moved to the Bay Area, and I feel like I've had more burritos in the past few weeks than during the rest of my life combined. That's not necessarily a bad thing, since most of the burritos I've had are pretty tasty -- this includes the super burrito I got at El Castillito.

Big, cheap, and good is all you need to know. Everything came to less than $10, even with a bottle of beer. It's a good thing I was hungry, because I don't think I could've finished the entire thing with a normal appetite.
