And as someone mentioned earlier, they use actual avocados, not guacamole, which makes a nice difference.
author: Chris M.

description:
They make one tasty, bad boy burrito (carne asada), and I'm from the Mission.  I order mine without the rice, so I don't have to pork out on the spot and I cannot afford to waltz back to work in a quasi-comatose state.  I am glad to see another solid reason to visit the TL/Civic Center to go along with Brenda's (on Polk), Philz Coffee (on Van Ness), Ananda Fuara's (on Market).

I haven't been too adventurous in trying their other items on the menu because I keep getting these mental images of how good the last carne asada was the last time I was there, and I order another one.  This is not a bad thing and my co-workers seem to be spellbound by the delicious grilled meat and fresh salsa smell.  It tastes every bit as good as it smells.  I also love their ice-cold green tomatillo sauce as a perfect complement.

Caveat:  forget the El Castillito one down the block closer to Leavenworth - they make theirs dry and just not very tasty (if they are related, it's clear they didn't share their recipe with each other).  Wouldn't go back there, no.  But the El Castillito on Larkin (across from the fed bldg) is a HELLS yeah, I'm comin' back!  

5-stars.
author: Roger R.

description: Very solid taqueria. This is my go-to burrito spot. It's not the best I've ever had, but it's definitely up there. And it's the best and most authentic Mexican in this part of the city. I pretty much always get the carne asada super burrito, either regular or wet. The meat is flavorful and juicy, and they pack a LOT of it into the burrito, every time. I love how they slice fresh avocado into it instead of guacamole.. that's how it should be! The dudes who prepare the food are friendly, and even though it's cash only, it's pretty cheap. I wish the chips were fresh and/or better. But that's not what I come here for. The portions are ginormous, but I almost never have leftovers because I'm a burrito destroyer.
author: Betsy W.

description:
The conveniently close location of El Castillito to my new office fits quite nicely into my "all burrito, all the time" diet.  As others have noted, the burritos are HUGE, but filled with delicious, fresh ingredients.  I've been equally pleased with both the carne asada and chicken versions of the burrito, and will undoubtedly soon be tempted by the carnitas dangling alluringly from the spit.  You have your choice of fillings, and definitely go for the spicy salsa.  The first time I bit into an El Castillito burrito, I thought they had given me the white girl version of the spicy salsa, but a few more bites past the chopped tomatoes and onions and into the coarsely chopped peppers proved otherwise.

Perfect for lunch with enough left over for dinner.

Update: I am adding an extra star for the fact that they always are really cool about letting me take my dog in with me for my take-out orders (and judging by the guy asking me if my burrito was to go or for here, perhaps letting me eat inside with him?!)  Maybe one day he will look more like a face-eater and less like a Muppet, but until that day there is no way in hey-ell that I'm tying him up outside in that hood.
author: Tanya N.

description: Castillito means little castle. Castles represent power and protection. The veggie burritos at Castillito provide power and protection from hangover, and also taste pretty good. Their chips however, taste like ass. Still, this place remains my favorite taqueria.
author: Ian T.

description:
3.5 Stars

Ok, I'm a fan of this place for a couple of reasons. Mainly because I can practically fall out of bed and land in the place, and secondly because it's decent, yummy, well priced mexican food with a smile. Oh, and free chips and salsa. 

Cafeteria style seating. Ugly, but clean.

If this is near you, great - go for it! Totally worth it. If you're driving across town, just go to the mission.
author: Mindy L.

description:
GIANT burritos the size of newborn babies.  decent carne asada and pollo asado.  i think they recently increased their prices though, so a super burrito is now about $6 plus tax.  and, since it's right around the corner from my digs, i like to roll out of bed around noon and walk there in my sweats, unshowered.  what can i say?  you gotta be classy to survive in the 'loin.

edit:  i found a giant pig bone in my carnitas burrito.  =(  minus one!
author: Katherine K.

description:
Great staff, and the clientele tells you that this is a Good Place. Sketchy neighborhood is a plus when it comes to taquerias. 

Hint: if you're feeling brave, go off the beaten track and try some cabeza or lengua here. Awe-inspiring.
author: jim b.

description: Love this place great people great food.  Really nice people and for around $5.00 you get  A LOT of food.  Fresh salsa, fresh everything.  Different kinds of tortillas like spinich and whole wheat.  Usually very fresh aqua fresca in seasonal fruits.  All really goood, I love to graba burrito here.  Parking great!
author: Ribec F.

description:
Came here one night after Movie Night in Mission Dolores park for some cheap eats, after I hung around with a co-worker and before coming here I went to Haight-Ashbury to smoke some Hookas, (I'm not really a smoker) but went and tried out, but not my thing.

Back to the story I went to this Taqueria because I was extremely hungry and had some Tacos Al Pastor, they were good but a bit greasy. Though the entertainment there was some Bums and a Mexican dude from Guanajuato who was a good singer who covered some popular Mexican songs and created his own Who went by the name of El Comico-The Comic, because he was a bit of a comedian.

Yea sure the place was a bit dumpy, but at least it was decent not bad, but not really good either filling though!
author: Alberto L.

description:
a sister shop to one up a few blocks,  this location needs a little maturing to match the standards of the other.

very immaculate with cafeteria type tables and chairs. open grill cooking and burritos made in plain sight. seeing the al postor on a spit, i should have ordered that. instead i had a carne asada burrito(4.65).

it consisted of  a scoop of refried rice, a scoop of black beans, a scoop of salsa, a pinch of seasoning, and lots of carne asada freshly grilled. i later added quacamole and some sauce from the salsa bar.
chips were gratis.

the burrito was mildly flavorful. with the added sauce, the burrito was passable. pretty good sized burrito.

pros:
burrito good size, good value
salsa bar, chips gratis
friendly service

cons:
parking is bad here on a normal day
burrito not very flavorful today
author: Victor G.

description: This location (250 Golden Gate) is no longer a El Castillito taqueria. It is now a Taqueria Chile Verde with different ownership.  This is the same taqueria that used to be on 6th st at Market which recently relocated here.  In my opinion it is the best taqueria in the civic center area!
author: Manuel R.

description:
This place really packs it in!  As I walked in to order a burrito afterwork, there was no line and only a couple people in the dining room.  Cool, no wait cause I was parked in a meter zone right out front.  

After I ordered, I saw the guy put the meat on the grill and that was ALOT of meat.  For me, the top thing about this place is that they have HUGE Burritos so if you are hungry, this is the place to go.  The Tortilla at the end seemed a little thick to me but hey, if you give a huge burrito to your customers, you better make sure all the fillings stay inside.  

Another thing they did different was they put some grilled green onions in there.  That's certainly not something I ever remember having in my burrito anywhere else.  

And to make it convenient, they also prepackage the salsa if you want extra so you don't have to do it yourself.  That was nice...  

I would definitely say that this is not one of my favorites but if I was in the neighborhood, I'd certainly come back around....
author: Mark W.

description: This place is great when you're in a rush to get some good Mexican food and Chipotle is too far away.  Actually, even if you're just looking for a great burrito at a great price, this is the spot.  I've been going back and forth between the super burrito and the super quesadilla.  Both are great and I really recommend getting carne asada.  They also give you free chips each time you go.  Neighborhood isn't the best, but I'm used to the TL and I'm guessing if you're thinking of eating here, you'd be too.  Go check 'em out, you won't regret it.
author: Robert I.

description: The wet burrito with carnitas is shmedium. Its dope because its close but I've had way better. What do you know about Taqueria Carolina in Tracy, Ca?
author: Jason M.

description: I eat here every once in a while. I work right up the block so it's an easy trek at break time. I am not the burrito fan that a lot of people are. It's just a bit too heavy for my tastes. That said, the breakfast burrito here, with chorizo, eggs, and salsa, is the bomb diggity. So good and so simple. The quesadilla castillito with carne asada is bomb too. Everything a burrito has, sin frijoles y arroz. I love it. A huge meal with drink for under ten bucks. You can't beat that
author: David G.

description: Hidden in the middle of the drug capital of SF is this delishous burrito spot. I would highly recommend the wheat tortia as it does not taste cardboardy like most other places. The prices are very reasonable and the portions pretty big.
author: Jen T.

description: Normally I go to the other El Castillito a few blocks up, but tried this one today. Seems like I'm entirely off-trend given the other reviews here, but the grilled chicken burrito I got was terrible. The meat was overly salty, the beans had no flavor at all, and the whole thing was oddly sweet. Like someone had accidentally used sugar in some part of the recipe instead of salt. Ick. Few bites in and I chucked it.
author: Mike R.

description:
My favorite! If I have enough moneys, I will definitely go here as the place of choice for any burrito. They are very good for not being within the Mission. I love love love their chicken. And the onions and stuff they put in the burritos. So good. Mmmmm. Everything is always good and they give lots of chips. Which is lovely

Be careful as it gets super crowded during lunch
author: Dustin H.

description: Good authentic Mexican food. Taco shop.
author: Mike P.

description:
I was shocked when I saw a review with one star! But I'm sure she just caught them on a bad day....which is rare there, as far as I'm concerned.

This place is freakin' awesome. I used to live in the TL for 3 years and this was one of the best places to grab a cheap meal. You can get a super meat burrito and a drink for under 10 bucks...and the burrito is gigantic, seriously. The rice to goodies (cheese, sour cream, gauc) ratio is pretty great as far as I'm concerned. So many places try to stuff them full of rice to make them bigger...it's a rip off. But not this place! 

The staff is really nice and they always remembered my usual when I came in. It's always clean for being in a shitty neighborhood also.  I'm glad I'm not in the TL anymore but I still have fond memories of this place and try to frequent it as often as I can.
author: Chris P.

description: Doesn't even touch el faralito. But overall an ok taco shop. They have tiny 99 cent tacos. Pastor was pretty decent, carne asada was below average.
author: Mike I.

description:
burritos of course; carnitas or carne asada w/sour cream.  Oh my!  

The problem of course is what to do when you get to the last 3 inches of that mother.  You know what's gonna happen if you finish it; you won't be good for anything except going home.  but you don't wanna try to save that last 3 inches, how sad!  So you finish it off, and suffer for the rest of the day....but oh how yummy it is!  And the salsa is so also very yummy, get extra!
And even with a line to wait in, it still goes very quickly!
author: Rebecca R.

description:
I've been going to the Church street location for a while.  Finally checked out the Golden Gate location.   Now the "lesser taqueria location" phenomenon is well established, but you never know how big the gap will be...  I am a huge fan of the Church location, so I did have some trepidation.

Yes, I did prefer the Church location, but the GG spot is definitely VERY good.  The torta and aqua fresca were both great.  The tables and staff were also good.  I'll definitely go there again if I'm in the area.
author: Stefan A.

description:
I've been by this place quite a bit but finally went it today for lunch.

I did dig the actual avocado in the burrito but I had the grilled chicken and it just wasn't quite there.  I love Pancho Villa's carne asada burritos so I probably should have got carne asada this time to compare.  I'll go back since it's a good deal and an independent local business which I love to support.
author: Gene X.

description:
Dry Dry Dry...  I understand I could've paid a bit more to get sour cream and guac and ect...  but I am a firm believer that a burrito can be flavorful and nice without those things.

The tortilla and the rice tasted like paper, and the meat was crumbled so tiny that it all fell apart when I took a bite.

I won't be coming back.
author: Joey O.

description: Ridiculously huge carne asada burrito for about $6. Cannot get this at Chipotle or in NYC. Everything is included ie. guac does not cost extra.  Apparently there's multiple "El Castillitos" around the area. Not sure what the difference between them is, but this one was excellent. Good lunch spot for Hastings students.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Every Friday for the past two years, I wander in here on the way home and buy a carne asada super burrito... at this point I don't even have to speak, they see me, and it's ready to go by the time I make it to register.

Yes it's in the TL, but it's my 'hood and I love this place.
author: Nikki M.

description:
El Castillito (the Little Castle) may not be the best burrito in town (Cuco's, La Corneta, and La Taqueria may have something to say about that), but it is certainly the King of Burritos in the Tenderloin.  Their setup is pretty standard for a San Francisco taqueria, but they make a pretty killer carne asada burrito, and I've enjoyed their carnitas as well.  

One thing I really like is that they always use avocado instead of guacamole.  This helps to prevent the dreaded soupy burrito, and adds a touch of freshness that you don't always find.  

Although for my daily lunch I'm more prone to go to Saigon Sandwich, some days I just need a burrito.  And when I do, El Castillito is the place to go.
author: jeremy f.

description:
So the burritos are ok and the chorizo and eggs are pretty satisfying...but the chips suck. They're definitely crappy storebought chips.

And it could be because I love sour cream and guacamole/avocado too much but everything tastes too dry here. Still, it seems to be the best Mexican food close to my work unless I feel like torturing myself with Chevy's food...
author: James Y.

description:
You know what sucks?  Getting food poisoning after eating a veggie burrito.  That should pretty much never happen.

Sure, the food tastes great going down.  And they are fairly nice there.  But YUCK.  Come on.
author: Katherine P.

description: Best....carnitas....EVER!  Get the Quesadilla Castillito with carnitas, spicy, everything.  You will not regret it!   Three choices of chicken, all great!  Gotta say, tho, their carne asada is stringy and bland.  Not good beef.  But the chx and pork make up for the cow.  99% of the time best chips ever!  Super cheap beer!  Not a vegan, but folks tell me its the best vege-burrito ever!  Hot sauce is habanero, so it's pretty hot!  GIANT burritos!  "Quesadillas" are made like burritos, w/o beans, so you can eat them without wearing them.  I prefer them because you get way more meat than in a burrito, which has lots of beans and lettuce.
author: Steve A.

description: $1 tacos. You can't go wrong. Second favorite Mexican food, in the city.
author: Sara G.

description: I tell ya.. you just can't find decent taquerias back in the east coast. I love these hole in the wall, no frills type of places. Pretty damn good burritos. Chips and priced right.. Chips? not so much.
author: Mark L.

description:
Omfg I had a great carne esada. Beats the crap out of chipotle any day.

Fluffy handmade flower tortilla with savory mozzerella melted on it before toppings get added.

They slice a fresh guacamole infront of you and scoop out until you say stop.

The mondo burrito was muy bueno, nice big and tasty.
author: Raymond F.

description:
My favorite burrito spot in sf by far, Taqueria El Castillito is a fav of area folks walking by other Taquerias for one of these gargantuan burritos. The people here are great! Though I can't say that every burrito in the city will have fresh ingredients, well seasoned meats or alternatives to the typical sf tortilla.... this place has it and more. If you're in the mood for a slight change from the burrito norm yet still crave cheesy, meaty goodness...... try their Quesadilla Castillito. Its basically a cross between a quesadilla with all the things you love in a burrito: Meat, cheese(of course) avacado, sour cream, tomatoes & jalapenos...... MMMMMMMMMMMMmmmmmm! 

Their prawns burrito is pretty popular and the pescado is mighty good. You'll end up paying $5-8 for your meal, chips & drink included, but its well worth it. This is where the burrito is at!
author: Eugene G.

description:
Not much to say about it.  It's definitely not a 5 star spot, but you gotta settle for what you can find when it's near school.

Quesadillas are big n' tasty.

Burritos are kinda bullshit

And the salsa they give you is mediocre
author: Michael P.

description: I come here for their $2.83 super taco w/ al pastor, sour cream, cheese, avocado, spicy salsa, cilantro & onions and the fresh fruit drinks.  Watermelon being my favorite.  I really enjoy how they don't charge extras for each of the fixins nor chips.  2 tacos gets me through the entire afternoon.
author: Stacey L.

description: Delicious burritos!  I love this place (they have another equally good location in the Castro), and especially enjoy their chorizo & egg burrito.
author: Jessica O.

description:
2 stars for the torta. I was not a fan. It could have possibly tasted amazing, but it smelled funky. Maybe if I plugged my nose it would have tasted better. 

oh btw, CASH ONLY!
author: Sati K.

description:
A great, tasty, big, burrito at a good price.  At around 4.50.   I'm from LA , so my friends in SF (who are also from LA) kept telling SF doesn't really have good Mexican food.  For the most part, they are right, but this place is really good and at a great price.  The burrito tastes great and is large enough to be eaten for lunch and dinner.   Was way better than that "Castillo B" place on Leavenworth. 

Here you pay less for more, which is wonderful!
author: Rusty W.

description: Mmmm.  Great burrito joint.  To get all the ingredients like avocado, go with the super burrito.  I was there for a dinner, so didn't get to see them go into burrito ninja mode to deal with the lunch crowds.  It also meant the ingredients were a tiny bit less fresh, a touch dry.  Still, a delicious, huge and definitely stuffing burrito, always a good decision.
author: Dano W.

description: Son of a bitch....they have tortas too???? I'm sold...best damn food in the TL. 4.50 for a big ass sandwich of awesomeness!
author: Nic K.

description: Located near my office i get to enjoy their yummy carnitas burritos and agua frescas when the cravings hit. Lunch there's always a line so go a few minuets early to beat the rush.
author: Jackie W.

description: I can't speak for the burritos but the tacos at this place just plain suck balls. Basically they do everything that they shouldn't with a taco. They complete overload the tortilla with a bunch of unnecessary bullshit making it completely impossible to pick up. Tacos with a fork anyone? I ordered the tacos to go and by the time I had walked the three blocks to my house the tortilla was completely soggy and ruined. Wack.
author: Tommy P.

description:
burritos are great quesadillas are great...always full...my god one of the best and worst feelings are being full and this place does it for me

more then enough to make me happy...
author: phillip w.

description: For the TL, the burrito is good, so I give it the extra star.  I'd generally rather go to the Mission, but it's good, so that's good.  For me.  It also is so big that it works splitting it for two.  I went with my friend Abraham, who suggested the split.  As he said, that's the first time I haven't felt nauseatingly full after eating here.   N.B. It's not the cheapest burrito.  Even two-on-one didn't make it Mission-price.
author: Laurel B.

description:
was cruising my six-block radius between the  morning fog and the late-afternoon wind sessions during that short window of warmed up sun and semi-naked people. decided to go get a burrito and headed down to golden gate avenue off larkin to El Castillito.  i haven't been here for ages, and noticed they had new management/staff but same menu items.  

had the extra large super burrito and asked if the cook can make it half chicken, the other half grilled pork.  i ordered a cantaloupe drink from the senorita and she was the first lady to describe how they make that rice water drink.

the burrito was a meal in itself, but took a couple of paper pans of chips - fresh, crispy, and corn flavor smacking the lips.  i wanted to 'lift' a few more pans for later but by the time i ate the burrito, i was too full to carry another gram on this obese body.  the food was so good, i almost had my stroke there ... it was that good.

try it if you haven't ... it is authentic and delicious.  they have beer if you want to drag your group there and get loud.  wish i had a half-pint of tequila to throw in my cantaloupe juice drink even though i am clean and sober ... i just wanted to party the burrito was so outstanding.
author: Tamara C.

description: Smothered burritos are pretty awesome.  They're _huge_ for around 6$.  One is easily two meals, especially with the included chips.  Pastor is tasty, carnitas were kind of bland.  Quick turn around (though I haven't been around for a lunch rush if there is one).  All that said, I wish they had a little more flavor - the salsa?  The rice?  Something seems under-seasoned.  Not the best, but very good.  Open 7 days a week, so they're great for a weekend hangover.
author: Stephen D.

description: I got 2 tacos with Carne Asada. It was jam packed and tasty. The place is in the Tenderloin, not my fav SF neighborhood. But if you are in the area, the tacos are worth it!
author: Jon M.

description:
Every now and then you wander around San Francisco's Civic Center, and suddenly your mind wanders around Mexican food, but you are not in the Mission, and then you happen to catch the slightest whiff of carnitas.  What would you do?

That happened to me last week. If you happen to wander around El Castillito on Golden Gate Avenue and Larkin Street, I would hope you wander in ask for their carnitas Supreme Nachos. 
Not me, smelled carnitas, but I was looking for carne asada tacos. 
No wait, it was three tacos al pastor and two carne asada tacos. 
While waiting in line (it was not that long) I saw the generous servings of meat, veggies, and beans these guys dealt with every dish on the menu. 
Wanna get healthy? Try their veggie burrito.

I wanted to be happy, and when I got my tacos with plenty of salsa verde and pico de gallo, and a full serving of tortilla chips, and my big horchata agua fresca, I knew I had to come back for more!
Thank you!
author: Art C.

description:
long lines at lunchtime, but one of the best chicken burritos i've tasted.  i especially like the huevos con chorizo and the chicken burritos.  the chips are definitely store bought, and the place is on the tiny side.  kinda pricey though...a chicken super burrito will set you back $7.51 and they charge for extra chips ($.50) and extra meat ($2.00)

i don't get the carne asada anymore as the meat has become tasteless and very, very dry.
author: Ray R.

description: Ok... I come here for one thing and one thing only... The super-prawn burrito! If you want the best prawn burrito in town, this place is the Taqueria to go to. I've never seen so much prawns grilled to perfection for one burrito. The super burrito consists of rice, beans, cheese, sour cream, salsa, fresh slices of avocado and a handful of chopped cilantro. YUMMALICIOUS. Ever since I've discovered the prawn burrito in the past month, I've been bringing friends who have discerning prawn burrito taste to check it out. And the consensus is unanimous... fricking licking good!
author: Christine C.

description: Great food and value. My favorite "healthy burrito": pollo verde can arroz, frijoles negros, lechuga y tomate en tortilla de espinaca -- ¡que rico!
author: DJandAlec D.

description:
El Castillito is my local taqueria. There's another one closer by, but these guys are much better and well worth the couple blocks' walk (and after eating one of these guys' zeppelins, you'll need it).

I went to another taqueria nearby to try it out. That was a mistake--they fumbled with the ingredients and left me with a rather bland, poorly-assembled burrito that took forever for them to put together. That sort of thing will not happen here. El Castillito's taqueria-ninjas assemble hefty burritos with lightning speed and precision that reminds me a Japanese sushi chef, or the German soccer team taking penalty kicks. The carne asada is pleasantly juicy, they're good about grilling your tortillia before making your burrito, the salsa is spicy but not overpowering (you can get it with mild salsa if you wish; they're also good about asking you what you want), and the overall experience is truly satisfying.

Favorite dish: super carne asada burrito, $6.35 out the door. I can finish one in one sitting if I'm fairly hungry, but I don't really need to eat for another ten or twelve hours.
author: Adam E.

description:
I honestly have San Francisco's Homosexual community to thank for discovering this place....

In May of 2003, the Pride Parade shut down Golden Gate near Larkin and, in a fit of starvation, I ended up at this place.

The burritos were and continue to be amazing for the following key reasons:

1) They cook your tortilla on the grill instead of steaming it like a wrinkled suit.

2) They top said tortilla with grated cheese (if you want) and get it all melted.  This is critical... nothing pisses me off more than these half-assed taquerias that add cheese last (on top of the cold salsa, etc.)

3) They actually throw the meat on the grill once more and get it all hot and crispy.  What a concept!  Again, half assed places spoon it right out of the soup....unacceptable.

4) They use slices of fresh avocado...way better that guacamole.  Especially when you're adding onions and salsa anyway.

5) They add cilantro on top of the meat....amazing.

All in all, they have the assembly of these things down to a science.  Every ingredient is prepared to its optimal flavor and then added to the burrito at the perfect stage.  The whole thing comes together in an orgy of flavor.  If I thought it wouldn't kill me, I'd eat a Carne Asada Super burrito every day.
author: Brian W.

description: It's in a less than savory locale, but drop in here to get yourself a good, hearty burrito for five bucks.  Already huge enough if you're starving, I'm afraid to see what the super burrito must look like.  Aside from burritos, they serve the requisite tacos, quesadillas, and nachos, along with plate specials and seafood.  There's a decent amount of seating for a taqueria if you choose to eat in.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I come to this location for lunch, but not as often as I should.  For about $6 I get a regular chicken burrito that I happen to love.  Yeah, it's my favorite lunch spot.  Seriously, I prefer these burritos to El Farolito.  I'm still feelin' Pancho Villa but because it's been a minute since I've been there, it's all about El Castillito.  Hell yeah.
author: Gina G.

description: I work down the street from here so it is a lunch time favorite when I forget my PB&J. The burritos are really fresh and tasty. The chicken is a bit greasy at times, but still very good. I like that they have wheat and spinach tortillas along with the regular stuff in case I am feeling wild-n-crazy that day.
author: Lilly O.

description: I've lived in the TL since Jan 07 and have yet to find a Mexican place like the ones in Fairfield, but this one is real close. The place is pretty low key Mom and Pop kinda resteraunt. I had to check it out after the reviews on Yelp. The regular borrito was huge....absolutely huge. I'm no dainty eater and I was stuffed. Honestly it could have been for 2 people. The pork was juicy and perfect (they really don't skimp on the meat here, The borrito was AT LEAST 1/2 filled w/ the delicious meat), the salsa added the right amount of heat, and all the flavors melded perfectly. I had this one to go but will have to try their other items there some time soon. Definitly a good place to go if your hungry in the TL.
author: Angelo F.

description: WTF?!  Why does this place have a 4 star review?!  I had dinner at this whole in the wall because it got good Yelp reviews and I'm a damn sucker for whole in the wall taquerias, but you people let me down!  Sure the staff was friendly, and there was a bathroom for me to use.  But I'm sorry, if you serve me cheese enchiladas with the cheese still COLD and HARD inside, then forget you!  I'll never frequent you again!
author: Michelle W.

description: This place makes a huge huge burrito.  I came here the other night together a super burrito and ended up with having enough for a large lunch the next day.  Maybe I just wasn't hungry enough, but this thing was huge.  I like the quality of the meat I thought it was good.  While it's not the best place in the city, it's pretty good for the area and I will probably be back here soon.
author: Sven S.

description: In my law school days, a few of us had a crush on one of the workers because of the absolute adorable way he'd ask us "Which beans?" (it had something to do with the tilt of his head and a smile, and the fact that we were incredibly bored while studying for the bar, so anything would entertain us). Now that I am blessed to work in the TL, its a regular lunch time stop. My personal fave are the quesadillas, because they are basically rice-less grilled burritos, and completely delicious. The tortas are also great- but word to the wise, don't get them with the green chile chicken, the chicken is too saucy for the bread and it turns into a gummy mess. Clearly, I come here too often.
author: Noelle Q.

description: pretty tasty pollo asado burrito.  The chef seemed like he was having a great time making it, which of course made my mouth water...
author: Matt V.

description: This place is pretty close to my house so I thought I would give it a shot with all the great reviews.  It is in a pretty seedy spot but such is the Tenderloin.  I got the carne asada super burrito.  It was very good but a bit dry for my taste, maybe more sour cream or salsa next time?  The people there were very friendly and polite.  The green salsa is very good but I wish they had a better red one.
author: JOHN G.

description: came here for a breakfast burrito as it seemed to be the only place in the area on yelp with one.  was hoping for a delicious burrito like I used to get in LA...sigh....no choice but chorizo.  The burrito consisted of ONLY chorizo, eggs, and salsa.  BLAH.  Was fairly cheap, but meh...couldnt even eat the whole thing...I mean come on....at least give me some cheese.  The horchata here is AWFUL here btw....I love horchata but it one ended up in the trash right outside the store.  disapointing :[
author: Brett T.

description: I miss this place so much! You have no idea. Since I've stopped working in TL, this is the one place I've been craving for lunch every Friday! Damnit! I miss the short guy, the taller guy, and the grumpy old man (who was never really grumpy with me).
author: Michael C.

description: Really solid burrito joint outside of the Mission, and might be the best one. I've spent many a meal here eating my fill. They grill the tortilla -- always a sign of quality -- and the burritos are huge. Huge. Just so you all know.
author: Geof M.

description:
these burritos are huge. like, way too big for a normal person to need.

but if you're a super-human, or just really hungry, hit it up.

(theyre good, and cheap, too!)
author: Dan M.

description:
Checked out this place based on reviews at http://www.burritophile.com/place.php?id=28

Got the super carne asada there, to go (with chips). I shoulda asked for some salsa or something cuz it was rather not spicy. I asked them to hold the sour cream cuz I've been meaning to eat healthier (yeah good idea going there). Anyway, the point is something was missing, it was still a rather good burrito (maybe too big). Liked the price $6.35

The way they do the beef is a bit intringuing, the meat is almost like, minced. Made for an easy bite

My biggest problems with burritos is how the tortilla kinda sticks to the roof of your mouth or on teeth. This was no exception

Seems to be a good eating option around Civic Center
author: xo x.

description:
this place embodies what i need in a food log.

their service places them above cancun on sixth. they smile and are friendly and they make what you order consistently. it is worth the weirdo walk to get there.

size matters and they have the girth to make it happen. the food log is always large. they make it WITH you

they fresh slice the avocadoes.
they have the green sauce.
they have the hot sauce.
they melt the cheeze, on the tortilla, on the grill, before it hits the foil.
they have carnitas.
the carne asada has minimal gristle! this is very importante.
they will fresh slice tomatoes upon request.
the plate dishes are generous.

they don't have 7up in a bottle. that's a bummer. THEY HAVE BEER.

ALL I CAN SAY IS THANK YOU AND TIP THEM THEY TAKE THE TIME TO DO IT RIGHT.
author: Joe P.

description:
my other favorite burrito joint.  if youre in the civic center area and need a great burrito, this is the place!

their al pastor is awesome, my favorite anywhere.  great tortas, good pollo verde, huge burritos.  nice fresh ingredients, never had a bad avocado there.  a bit weak on the quesadillas, probably not what youd expect.  tasty fresh taquitos, good camarones diablo.  but the burritos... :drool:

also, this place has awesome breakfast burritos.  huge!  you wont need to eat til dinner.  great stuff.

nice staff, decently sized place.  can get packed during lunch.  if youre in the area, go!  one of the best places outside of the mission.
author: Junglist S.

description: I love this place, affordable and you can taste the freshness in the food, the guy who prepares the food is grumpy in a funny way, he is actually got the perfect look for a mafia movie star!!!!!!!
author: dim l.

description: went in expecting a regular burrito, came out a fan, the prices are good for a big burrito, taste is good, ingredients seem fresh, would come back here again
author: Mike G.

description: Loved it. Sketchy location but great food and fabulously nice staff.
author: David G.

description: Awful. Raw chicken. No flavor. Unripe avocado. Bland rice. Something was definitely wrong with the refried beans. Sour cream was flavorless as well. Could only eat like a quarter of it before I gave up. Also, the picture above is of the Castillito on Church street, which is pretty decent, unlike this place, which has made me vow to never get a burrito in the Tenderloin again. Gross.
author: Del D.

description: the carnitas and other things here aren't bad, 6/10, but damn, go at lunch time when the grill is going and the carne asada is some of the best you'll taste.  i'm not joking.  unfortunately (and perhaps oddly), the same can't be said for this mini-chain's other locations.  the carne asada is best eaten on a taco, but if you get the burrito, the standard rule applies: if you value flavor, don't get cream or cheese.
author: David M.

description: I can't express enough gratitude for this place for being SOO damn good, despite it's desolate location in the grimy TL and small and dingy accomodations. The staff is SUPER friendly and luckily I know some spanish, so it's a fun time to talk to the ppl there. They have some really good chips and salsa and some of the best Burritos I have ever had (carne asada, veggie, pollo). (NOTE: I have had tons of burritos in socal and Mexico). The taco plate is really good, too. Oh - and they have wheat and veggie flour tortilla's - can you believe it?!?! THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU to El Castillito for all the nurishment during the last few years of final exam hell!!! :-D
author: sarah e.

description: happened to be meeting a friend in the area the other day and found myself slightly starving.  i forced myself to walk past a mcdonald's and several sketchy looking chinese joints in hopes of finding something better, and as it turns out, the willpower paid off.  the service was fast and the burrito was one of the best I've had in the city.  i had a carnitas with pintos, guac, and sour cream, but their asada looked great as well.  if you're in the TL looking for a burrito, i would come here over any other taqueria in the area.
author: Kevin D.

description: Like any good san franciscan, I have eaten exactly 14 burritos more than my share.  From the mission to baja noe valley; from parkside to russian hill; I can say without equivocation that my best burritos have come from El Castillito.  Situated on always delightful, never dull, Golden Gate Avenue, Castillito serves up fare to the Civic Center lunch crowd as well as the greedy legion of law students from the nearby school.  I being of the latter group have enjoyed Castillito a few times too many.  I always used to go for the carne asada super burrito with black beans and spicy salsa.  Nowadays I can't handle being full for 9 hours straight, so I just go for the vegeterian...its very good too.  Note to last reviewer: the reason the short guy wraps worse is because he puts way more stuff in his burritos!  So, if you want a cleaner experience, but with less value, then the tall skinny guy is the way to go.
author: Mr. G.

description: dirty side of  tendercracksville...well a step above chevy's choices. block over from Phil Burton Fed bldg.
author: miriam b.

description: This is my favorite taqueria in San Francisco. I drive here from Potrero Hill to pick up burritos for my crew. They have excellent carnitas and pollo verde. Not fancy, not very appealing on the eyes, not in the best neighborhood but amazing burritos and quesadilla. Best of all --- super cheap and they always have ripe avocados.
author: lilalaune12

description: yummmmm. Just ate a prawn burrito from here and it was perfecto! What I look for in a burrito is fresh ingredients and the perfect amount of rice,beans, cheese, meat, salsa, sour cream and guac. This place met my expectations, the best part being the fresh delicious prawns (and a generous helping of them).  If you love burritos like I do, you will definitely appreciate El Castillito in the TL.
author: Rebecca S.

description: clean restaurant with friendly staff. i like how they put the salsa on ice and you watch them grill the meat to order. my favorite burrito in the area.
author: james y.
